title: How to Make a Tweeting Bird in a Cage from Plastic Straws

steps.headline: Follow the cutting lines shown on the figure below for this step.
steps.description: Cut a wing-part from the straw. Note that it's divided into two sections by the concertina part of the straw. The wing section is shorter than the backbone.

steps.headline: Use the short wing piece for this step.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Bcb2_775.JPG/460px-Bcb2_775.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Bcb2_775.JPG/760px-Bcb2_775.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Cut open the short wing piece as shown.

steps.headline: Using your fingers, press out the cut wing piece.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Bcb4_122.JPG/459px-Bcb4_122.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Bcb4_122.JPG/759px-Bcb4_122.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Then, fold the wing piece in half, as shown.

steps.headline: Cut out symmetrical wings on both sides of the fold.
steps.description: Make sure to keep the wings connected at the middle.

steps.headline: Cut small slits around the bottom edge to make the feathery tips.
steps.description: It is helpful to enlarge this picture to see the extent of the feathering required.

steps.headline: Take the other half of the straw.
steps.description:
In this part, you will be shaping the tail and the backbone. Refer back to the diagram in step 1 for the correct cutting points. Press down on the straw on either side of the concertina part of the straw. Don't flatten the concertina part itself, however. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/DVC00231_320.JPG/460px-DVC00231_320.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/27/DVC00231_320.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Leaving a little even space on each side of the folded line, start cutting down the backbone piece of the straw following alongside the folded edge, as shown. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/DVC00232_514.JPG/460px-DVC00232_514.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d9/DVC00232_514.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Continue cutting this piece until you reach the concertina portion of the straw.

steps.headline: Take hold of the remaining uncut portion and cut it in half by cutting down the other folded line.
steps.description:
This will divide the remaining piece exactly in half. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/DVC00235_292.JPG/460px-DVC00235_292.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4e/DVC00235_292.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}As before, continue cutting down the folded line until you reach the concertina part of the straw.

steps.headline: Arrange the pieces.
steps.description: The piece that is still folded is the backbone and tail. See the image, the fatter piece is still folded and is the piece that was cut alongside the folded line, not on it.

steps.headline: Form the bird's neck.
steps.description:
Take the concertina part of the straw and bend it into what looks like a bird's neck shape. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/DVC00240_35.JPG/460px-DVC00240_35.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/23/DVC00240_35.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Sideways view Try to approximate how it appears here.

steps.headline: Form the bird's beak.
steps.description:
Turn the straw around to the shorter end above the concertina part. Return to the figure set out in step 1 and follow the exact cutting points outlined there. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/DVC00243_772.JPG/460px-DVC00243_772.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/69/DVC00243_772.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Pull the cut piece away to reveal the beak shape.

steps.headline: Return to the longer side of the straw below the concertina portion.
steps.description: Take each of the wide pieces and bend them, then wrap them around the backbone piece, as shown. You're about to create a knot at this point. Refer back to previous steps to help you keep track of each piece.

steps.headline: Ensure that a loophole has been created and hold the two fat pieces between your fingers, just prior to pulling into a knot.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/DVC00247_751.JPG/460px-DVC00247_751.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c2/DVC00247_751.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Pull into shape to create a neat and symmetrical knot. Don't make it too tight as you'll need to loosen it shortly for adding the wings. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/DVC00248_425.JPG/460px-DVC00248_425.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/03/DVC00248_425.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}The two fat pieces (the legs that will slide into the cage piece) should be facing forward when you are finished, in front of the neck and below the beak.

steps.headline: Loosen the knot to create a small space.
steps.description: Slide the wings through this space and ensure that they're sitting evenly. Retighten the knot.

steps.headline: Finish up by tidying the short tail.
steps.description:
Cut off the long piece so that a short tail remains, as shown by the image. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Bcb10_129.JPG/460px-Bcb10_129.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Bcb10_129.JPG/760px-Bcb10_129.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Feather the tail. As with the wings, make small evenly spaced slits to create a feathered tail look. You can stop here if you want just a bird, or you can proceed to making a cage for it as well, as outlined in Part 2.

steps.headline: View the figure provided here to help you understand which parts are created to form the cage.
Cut the straw.
steps.description: Following the image provided in step 1 of Part 2, cut the straw into eight equal parts, lengthwise. The cuts should only come as far as the valley fold line indicated on the figure.

steps.headline: Fold each of the eight parts.
steps.description: Following the figure, you will need to make both mountain and valley folds, as outlined on the figure. Valley folds: Pull each of the eight pieces out from the straw (toward you if you're rotating the straw) and bend into position. The valley fold extends from the point where you ended cutting the eight pieces. Mountain folds: Looking at the diagram in Step 1, Part 2, fold each of the eight pieces that have been folded outward up toward you so that stick up like a mountain.

steps.headline: Cut off a small portion of the uncut end of the straw.
steps.description:
You are going to be using this piece as a ring to thread over the other part of the straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Bcc5_470.JPG/460px-Bcc5_470.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Bcc5_470.JPG/760px-Bcc5_470.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} The resulting ring seen apart from the rest of the straw.

steps.headline: Place the ring at the top of the eight thin mountain pieces.
steps.description:
Make sure each piece is included; this may take some steady handwork. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Bcc7_557.JPG/459px-Bcc7_557.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Bcc7_557.JPG/758px-Bcc7_557.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":343,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":566.5454545454545,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Thread it to about three quarters of the way down the cut straw pieces, as shown here.

steps.headline: Create curls.
steps.description:
The curls are designed to prevent the ring piece from slipping off the cage when you push it back up toward the top. Take the ends of each cut piece of straw and roll it over firmly to create a curl shape. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Bcc9_678.JPG/460px-Bcc9_678.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a7/Bcc9_678.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":616,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1018.1818181818181,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Repeat for each piece until all are curled.

steps.headline: Push the ring back up toward the top, sitting just under the curled parts of the cage.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Bcc11_348.JPG/459px-Bcc11_348.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Bcc11_348.JPG/759px-Bcc11_348.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Pull out the valley/mountain folds evenly to form the sides of the cage. Adjust until the entire structure sits together properly and looks like a cage.

steps.headline: Gently slide your bird made in Part 1 into the cage.
steps.description: The legs should slide straight into the hollow at the base of the cage.

steps.headline: Adjust so that the bird appears to be singing from through the bars of the cage.
steps.description: Enjoy your tweeting bird, or if you made it in blue, your "Twitter bird", in its cage!

text:
Making the tweeting bird Follow the cutting lines shown on the figure below for this step. Cut a wing-part from the straw. Note that it's divided into two sections by the concertina part of the straw. The wing section is shorter than the backbone. Use the short wing piece for this step. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Bcb2_775.JPG/460px-Bcb2_775.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Bcb2_775.JPG/760px-Bcb2_775.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

Using your fingers, press out the cut wing piece. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Bcb4_122.JPG/459px-Bcb4_122.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Bcb4_122.JPG/759px-Bcb4_122.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

Cut small slits around the bottom edge to make the feathery tips. It is helpful to enlarge this picture to see the extent of the feathering required. Take the other half of the straw. In this part, you will be shaping the tail and the backbone. Refer back to the diagram in step 1 for the correct cutting points. Press down on the straw on either side of the concertina part of the straw. Don't flatten the concertina part itself, however. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/DVC00231_320.JPG/460px-DVC00231_320.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/27/DVC00231_320.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":613,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1013.3333333333334,"licensing":"

Slide the wings through this space and ensure that they're sitting evenly. Retighten the knot. Finish up by tidying the short tail. Cut off the long piece so that a short tail remains, as shown by the image. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Bcb10_129.JPG/460px-Bcb10_129.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Bcb10_129.JPG/760px-Bcb10_129.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

"}Feather the tail. As with the wings, make small evenly spaced slits to create a feathered tail look. You can stop here if you want just a bird, or you can proceed to making a cage for it as well, as outlined in Part 2. Making the cage View the figure provided here to help you understand which parts are created to form the cage. Cut the straw. Following the image provided in step 1 of Part 2, cut the straw into eight equal parts, lengthwise. The cuts should only come as far as the valley fold line indicated on the figure. Fold each of the eight parts. Following the figure, you will need to make both mountain and valley folds, as outlined on the figure. Valley folds: Pull each of the eight pieces out from the straw (toward you if you're rotating the straw) and bend into position. The valley fold extends from the point where you ended cutting the eight pieces. Mountain folds: Looking at the diagram in Step 1, Part 2, fold each of the eight pieces that have been folded outward up toward you so that stick up like a mountain. Cut off a small portion of the uncut end of the straw. You are going to be using this piece as a ring to thread over the other part of the straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Bcc5_470.JPG/460px-Bcc5_470.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Bcc5_470.JPG/760px-Bcc5_470.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} The resulting ring seen apart from the rest of the straw. Place the ring at the top of the eight thin mountain pieces. Make sure each piece is included; this may take some steady handwork. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Bcc7_557.JPG/459px-Bcc7_557.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Bcc7_557.JPG/758px-Bcc7_557.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":343,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":566.5454545454545,"licensing":"

"} Thread it to about three quarters of the way down the cut straw pieces, as shown here. Create curls. The curls are designed to prevent the ring piece from slipping off the cage when you push it back up toward the top. Take the ends of each cut piece of straw and roll it over firmly to create a curl shape. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Bcc9_678.JPG/460px-Bcc9_678.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a7/Bcc9_678.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":616,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1018.1818181818181,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

"}Repeat for each piece until all are curled. Push the ring back up toward the top, sitting just under the curled parts of the cage. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Bcc11_348.JPG/459px-Bcc11_348.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Bcc11_348.JPG/759px-Bcc11_348.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image by: Uploader

"}Pull out the valley/mountain folds evenly to form the sides of the cage. Adjust until the entire structure sits together properly and looks like a cage. Combining the two pieces Gently slide your bird made in Part 1 into the cage. The legs should slide straight into the hollow at the base of the cage. Adjust so that the bird appears to be singing from through the bars of the cage. Enjoy your tweeting bird, or if you made it in blue, your "Twitter bird", in its cage!
